Imagine you get old, you know your time is almost up, so you say goodbye to your friends and family and make your way to your local end of life center. It's raining outside, the light roll of thunder in the distance but not close enough to feel. You and hundreds of others enter the facility broken into even length single file lines. You look at those around you: poor, wealthy, somewhere in the middle, all equal at the end. You're directed through the doors, made to strip, then led by staff to a large door bearing the words "NO CONTRACEPTIVE BEYOND THIS POINT." The door opens, revealing a massive, warehouse sized, room filled with hundreds of other people. You know what you must do. You know what your life was for, and you've known since the day you were born how it was going to end. You step inside. You see people streaming in from all sides of the massive room. The flow of footsteps stop. The last person steps in, followed by the sound of their door closing with a quiet, soft, click much like the doors of a doctor's office.

A whistle blows, and the death orgy begins.

comment_text: Damn I was hoping this tree would swim and taste delicious

Isn't this the strategy used by bamboos. They grow fast, survive for up to 50-60 years (some species), then suddenly flower before dying. Bamboos being of grass family does this to overwhelm the predators.

That is why in ancient times, bamboo flowering was associated with famine, at least in India. The abundance of food (bamboo seeds) for the rodent species meant even faster increase in their population considering their fast reproduction and growth rates. These increased rodent population would then inevitably target the nearby granaries and farms, resulting in famines.

I still don't understand why they die after releasing their seeds.
The video says T. vasquezii grow much faster than their polycarp neighbors because the T. vasquezii, "put all of its energy into growth until it reproduces. Other trees have to devote a ton of resources into reproduction every year, so they don't grow as quickly." But to me, that doesn't fully explain why they die after reaching maturity and releasing seeds. Otherwise, it would make more sense for them to not release seeds for the first 49 years, like they do now, so that they can put all their energy into growing quickly but then whenever they reach maturity they could just release the seeds without dying.
Once they reach that height, why not continue to release seeds? Perhaps they deplete the soils where they grow from certain nutrients from their rapid growth and that's why they die after the release of seeds?
Well, not all monocarpic trees are successful. There are plenty of examples of endangered monocarpic palm trees (well, palms technically are not true trees but close enough).

You didn't mention bamboos. Although not a tree, many species reproduce in this same manner. I witnessed this in a stand of bamboo, in Japan, that was at least 100 years old. It was quite a sight.

So it’s like an annual that just takes a bunch of years to reach reproductive age, instead of just one growing season.  There are desert plans like silversword or century plant that use the same strategy.
Imagine being an old tree developing for years to build strong fiber and developing leaves just to give birth then die

Bamboo species are also monocarpic, though they probably do it because of the open canopy hypothesis

Bamboos are grasses and grow from a underground rhizome that sends up many shoots. As a result, a single bamboo plant can become a small forest unto itself. Furthermore, bamboo seeds, called bamboo rice, are simply dropped onto the ground before the parent plant dies. If bamboos were polycarpic, juvenile plants would be at a serious competitive disadvantage against their parent plants not just for light, but water, nutrients, and surface access
